procedure: Inpatient Admission Evaluation – Acute Uncomplicated Sigmoid Diverticulitis (K57.92)

workflowSteps.details: Ingested inpatient authorization form, clinical summary, UR packet, structured medical records JSON, CT imaging reports, and laboratory results
workflowSteps.outcome: All required documents successfully processed - 15 documents including medical records, imaging, and lab results
workflowSteps.comments: Document quality excellent - comprehensive clinical documentation with complete imaging and laboratory data

workflowSteps.details: Extracted comprehensive patient demographics, insurance information, provider details, facility information, diagnosis codes, and service type from authorization request
workflowSteps.outcome: Patient: Amanda Latoya Williams (38F, DOB: 03/05/1987), Member ID: U7183854101, Ambetter-ATC insurance, Admitted: 04/24/2025
workflowSteps.comments: Insurance verification successful - active coverage confirmed with Ambetter-ATC contracted plan, requesting provider: Benjamin Velky, NPI: 1083063507, facility: Self Regional HE

workflowSteps.details: Analyzed vital signs, laboratory tests (CBC, CMP, BMP, UA), CT abdomen/pelvis imaging results, medical history, and current medications
workflowSteps.outcome: Vitals stable: BP 138/84, HR 78, Temp 98.1°F, SpO2 100%. Labs: Normal WBC, no leukocytosis. CT: Uncomplicated sigmoid diverticulitis without abscess, perforation, or pericolonic complications
workflowSteps.comments: Patient hemodynamically stable, afebrile, no signs of sepsis or systemic toxicity. Clinical presentation consistent with uncomplicated diverticulitis suitable for outpatient management

workflowSteps.details: Evaluated inpatient admission criteria against InterQual guidelines and AAFP evidence-based criteria for acute diverticulitis management
workflowSteps.outcome: Medical necessity score for inpatient: 32% (Low) - Patient does not meet criteria for inpatient admission. Outpatient management appropriate with oral antibiotics and dietary modification
workflowSteps.comments: Patient lacks high-risk features: no fever, no significant leukocytosis, no imaging complications, no immunosuppression, tolerating oral intake, stable vital signs. AAFP guidelines support outpatient management

workflowSteps.details: Verified inpatient authorization requirements against Ambetter coverage criteria and CMS guidelines for acute care admissions
workflowSteps.outcome: Inpatient admission criteria NOT met - policy requires presence of complications (abscess, perforation), hemodynamic instability, sepsis, or inability to tolerate oral intake
workflowSteps.comments: Coverage criteria strictly define inpatient necessity. Current clinical presentation does not meet any threshold criteria for inpatient authorization

workflowSteps.details: Calculated estimated costs for inpatient admission versus outpatient management with antibiotics and follow-up care
workflowSteps.outcome: Inpatient admission: $12,500-15,000 (3-day stay). Outpatient management: $800-1,200 (medications, follow-up visits, imaging if needed). Cost savings: $11,700
workflowSteps.comments: Outpatient management is cost-effective and clinically appropriate, avoiding unnecessary hospitalization costs while maintaining quality care

workflowSteps.details: Evaluated clinical risks associated with outpatient management including risk of progression, complications, and readmission potential
workflowSteps.outcome: Low risk for outpatient management - 5% risk of progression requiring hospitalization. Patient has no high-risk comorbidities, stable social support (emergency contact available)
workflowSteps.comments: Risk factors assessed: BMI 40.9 (obesity), diabetes mellitus, hypertension - all well-controlled. Patient appropriate for outpatient care with safety-net instructions

workflowSteps.details: Comprehensive review of AAFP evidence-based guidelines, ACG clinical guidelines for diverticulitis, and institutional protocols for uncomplicated diverticulitis
workflowSteps.outcome: All major clinical guidelines support outpatient management for uncomplicated diverticulitis without systemic signs of infection or complications
workflowSteps.comments: Evidence strongly supports selective outpatient management with oral antibiotics (Ciprofloxacin + Metronidazole already prescribed) and dietary modifications

workflowSteps.details: Convened physician panel review due to inpatient admission request conflicting with clinical guideline recommendations. Panel consisted of gastroenterologist, hospitalist, and medical director
workflowSteps.outcome: Panel consensus: DENY inpatient admission. Unanimous agreement that clinical presentation does not warrant inpatient care. Outpatient management appropriate with close follow-up
workflowSteps.comments: Panel noted patient already receiving appropriate antibiotic therapy (Ciprofloxacin 500mg, Metronidazole 500mg). Clear liquid to low-residue diet recommended with 48-72 hour follow-up

workflowSteps.details: Developed comprehensive outpatient care plan including medication regimen, dietary modifications, symptom monitoring, and follow-up schedule
workflowSteps.outcome: Recommended outpatient plan: Continue current antibiotics (7-10 day course), clear liquid diet progressing to low-residue, oral analgesics (current: Hydrocodone-acetaminophen PRN), follow-up in 48-72 hours
workflowSteps.comments: Safety-net instructions provided: Return to ED if fever >101°F, worsening abdominal pain, persistent vomiting, inability to tolerate oral intake, or signs of peritonitis. Patient education materials provided

workflowSteps.details: Generated final denial determination with detailed clinical rationale and alternative care recommendations
workflowSteps.outcome: Authorization #PA-2024-007-DENIED issued for inpatient admission. Denial letter sent to provider and facility with comprehensive justification and outpatient care plan
workflowSteps.comments: Decision communicated to Self Regional HE UR Department via secure portal with complete audit trail

keyFindings.clinicalJustification: Patient afebrile, hemodynamically stable, normal WBC, CT shows uncomplicated sigmoid diverticulitis without abscess/perforation. Outpatient management appropriate.
keyFindings.medicalNecessity: Inpatient admission not clinically indicated; outpatient care recommended per guidelines.
keyFindings.policyCompliance: Meets all policy criteria for denial; inpatient admission requires systemic toxicity, hemodynamic instability, or imaging complications.
keyFindings.costEfficiency: Avoids unnecessary hospitalization costs; outpatient management is cost-effective and guideline concordant.

denialDetails.denialReason: Inpatient admission does not meet medical necessity criteria - clinical presentation appropriate for outpatient management
denialDetails.deniedBy: IPAS Automated System with Physician Panel Review
denialDetails.reviewType: Automated Initial Denial with Physician Panel Consensus Review

reviewPanel.hospitalist: Dr. James O'Connor, MD - Hospital Medicine
reviewPanel.medicalDirector: Dr. Patricia Chen, MD, MBA - Medical Director

coverageDetails.inpatientCare: DENIED - Does not meet inpatient admission criteria per policy guidelines
coverageDetails.outpatientCare: COVERED AND RECOMMENDED - Oral antibiotics (Ciprofloxacin 500mg BID + Metronidazole 500mg TID for 7-10 days), dietary modifications (clear liquid progressing to low-residue diet), oral analgesics for pain management, follow-up visit within 48-72 hours

recommendations.immediate: Outpatient management with clear liquid to low residue diet, analgesics (Hydrocodone-acetaminophen 7.5-325mg PRN), and continue current antibiotic regimen (Ciprofloxacin 500mg BID + Metronidazole 500mg TID)
recommendations.followUp: Re-evaluate within 48-72 hours with primary care provider or gastroenterologist. Clinical assessment to include vital signs, abdominal exam, and symptom progression evaluation
recommendations.monitoring: Safety-net instructions: Monitor for fever >101°F, worsening abdominal pain, persistent vomiting, inability to tolerate oral intake, rectal bleeding, or signs of peritonitis. Immediate ED evaluation if any warning signs develop
recommendations.education: Comprehensive patient education provided on dietary modifications (clear liquids day 1-2, progress to low-residue diet as tolerated), medication compliance, importance of adequate hydration, activity restrictions, and recognition of warning symptoms requiring immediate medical attention
recommendations.dietaryRecommendations: Clear liquid diet initially (broth, gelatin, clear juices), advance to low-residue diet as symptoms improve (white bread, white rice, cooked vegetables without skins), avoid high-fiber foods, nuts, seeds, and raw vegetables during acute phase
recommendations.medicationManagement: Complete full 7-10 day antibiotic course even if symptoms improve. Take probiotics after antibiotic completion to restore gut flora. Continue current medications for diabetes and hypertension as prescribed

clinicalReferences.evidence: Multiple high-quality studies demonstrate safety and efficacy of outpatient management for uncomplicated diverticulitis with low rates of treatment failure (5-7%) and complications (<2%). Hinchey Grade 0-1 diverticulitis without systemic signs does not require hospitalization per current evidence.
